member.name: T:System.Windows.Controls.InteractionHelper
member.summary: The InteractionHelper provides controls with support for all of the common interactions like mouse movement, mouse clicks, key presses, etc., and also incorporates proper event semantics when the control is disabled.

member.name: F:System.Windows.Controls.InteractionHelper.SequentialClickThresholdInMilliseconds
member.summary: The threshold used to determine whether two clicks are temporally local and considered a double click (or triple, quadruple, etc.). 500 milliseconds is the default double click value on Windows. This value would ideally be pulled form the system settings.

member.name: F:System.Windows.Controls.InteractionHelper.SequentialClickThresholdInPixelsSquared
member.summary: The threshold used to determine whether two clicks are spatially local and considered a double click (or triple, quadruple, etc.) in pixels squared. We use pixels squared so that we can compare to the distance delta without taking a square root.

member.name: F:System.Windows.Controls.InteractionHelper._updateVisualState
member.summary: Reference used to call UpdateVisualState on the base class.

member.name: M:System.Windows.Controls.InteractionHelper.#ctor(System.Windows.Controls.Control)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the InteractionHelper class.

member.name: M:System.Windows.Controls.InteractionHelper.UpdateVisualState(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Update the visual state of the control.
member.param: A value indicating whether to automatically generate transitions to the new state, or instantly transition to the new state.
member.remarks: UpdateVisualState works differently than the rest of the injected functionality. Most of the other events are overridden by the calling class which calls Allow, does what it wants, and then calls Base. UpdateVisualState is the opposite because a number of the methods in InteractionHelper need to trigger it in the calling class. We do this using the IUpdateVisualState internal interface.

member.name: M:System.Windows.Controls.VisualTreeExtensions.GetLogicalChildrenBreadthFirst(System.Windows.FrameworkElement)
member.summary: Retrieves all the logical children of a framework element using a breadth-first search. A visual element is assumed to be a logical child of another visual element if they are in the same namescope. For performance reasons this method manually manages the queue instead of using recursion.
member.returns: The logical children of the framework element.

member.name: M:System.Windows.Controls.AutoCompleteBox.TryGetSelectionAdapter(System.Object)
member.summary: Returns the specified object as an ISelectionAdapter, if possible.
member.param: The object to retrieve as an ISelectionAdapter.
member.returns: A ISelectionAdapter object, if possible. Otherwise, null reference (Nothing in Visual Basic).
member.remarks: This method returns the specified object as an ISelectionAdapter to provide the selection adaptor for the drop-down portion of the AutoCompleteBox control. If the specified object implements ISelectionAdapter or derives from Selector, it will automatically be returned as an ISelectionAdapter object; otherwise TryGetSelectionAdapter returns a null reference (Nothing in Visual Basic). To provide a custom selection mechanism, override this method in a derived class and return your custom selection adapter as an ISelectionAdapter.

member.param: A nullable bool value indicating whether the action was user initiated. In a user initiated mode, the underlying text dependency property is updated. In a non-user interaction, the text box value is updated. When user initiated is null, all values are updated.

member.summary: Handle the update of the text for the control from any source, including the TextBox part and the Text dependency property.

member.name: M:System.Windows.Controls.AutoCompleteBox.PopulateComplete
member.summary: Notifies the AutoCompleteBox that the ItemsSource property has been set and the data can be filtered to provide possible matches in the drop-down.
member.remarks: Call this method when you are providing custom population of the drop-down portion of the AutoCompleteBox, to signal the control that you are done with the population process. Typically, you use PopulateComplete when the population process is a long-running process and you want to cancel built-in filtering of the ItemsSource items. In this case, you can handle the Populated event and set PopulatingEventArgs.Cancel to true. When the long-running process has completed you call PopulateComplete to indicate the drop-down is populated.

member.name: M:System.Windows.Controls.AutoCompleteBox.UpdateTextCompletion(System.Boolean)

member.summary: Gets or sets the minimum number of characters required to be entered in the text box before the AutoCompleteBox displays possible matches.
member.value: The minimum number of characters to be entered in the text box before the AutoCompleteBox displays possible matches. The default is 1.
member.remarks: If you set MinimumPrefixLength to -1, the AutoCompleteBox will not provide possible matches. There is no maximum value, but setting MinimumPrefixLength to value that is too large will prevent the AutoCompleteBox from providing possible matches as well.

member.remarks: You use the ItemTemplate property to specify the visualization of the data objects in the drop-down portion of the AutoCompleteBox control. If your AutoCompleteBox is bound to a collection and you do not provide specific display instructions by using a DataTemplate, the resulting UI of each item is a string representation of each object in the underlying collection.

member.name: T:System.Windows.Controls.SelectorSelectionAdapter
member.summary: Represents the selection adapter contained in the drop-down portion of an AutoCompleteBox control.

remarks.para: This class wraps a Selector control and implements the ISelectionAdapter interface. A selection adapter is a part required by the AutoCompleteBox control template. The SelectorSelectionAdapter provides custom behavior for the AutoCompleteBox control, such as an item collection, selection members, and key handling.
You can create a new template for the AutoCompleteBox and provide your own ISelectionAdapter to provide custom selection functionality without deriving from the AutoCompleteBox class.

member.name: M:System.Windows.Controls.SelectorSelectionAdapter.HandleKeyDown(System.Windows.Input.KeyEventArgs)
member.summary: Provides handling for the KeyDown event that occurs when a key is pressed while the drop-down portion of the AutoCompleteBox has focus.
member.remarks: This method is called by the KeyDown event of the AutoCompleteBox, when the drop-down portion of the AutoCompleteBox has focus. This method marks the KeyDown event of the AutoCompleteBox as handled when one of the following keys is pressed: Enter The HandleKeyDown method raises the Commit event when the Enter key is pressed. The method raises the Cancel event when the Escape key is pressed.
member.param: A KeyEventArgs that contains data about the KeyDown event.

member.name: M:System.Windows.Controls.SelectorSelectionAdapter.OnCommit
member.summary: Raises the Commit event.
member.remarks: Raising an event invokes the event handler through a delegate. The OnCommit method also allows derived classes to handle the event without attaching a delegate. This is the preferred technique for handling the event in a derived class. Notes to Inheritors: When overriding OnCommit in a derived class, be sure to call the base classs OnCommit method so that registered delegates receive the event.

member.name: M:System.Windows.Controls.SelectorSelectionAdapter.OnCommit(System.Object,System.Windows.RoutedEventArgs)
member.summary: Fires the Commit event.

member.name: M:System.Windows.Controls.SelectorSelectionAdapter.OnCancel
member.summary: Raises the Cancel event.
member.remarks: Raising an event invokes the event handler through a delegate. The OnCancel method also allows derived classes to handle the event without attaching a delegate. This is the preferred technique for handling the event in a derived class. Notes to Inheritors: When overriding OnCancel in a derived class, be sure to call the base classs OnCancel method so that registered delegates receive the event.

member.name: M:System.Windows.Controls.SelectorSelectionAdapter.CreateAutomationPeer
member.summary: Returns an automation peer for the underlying Selector control, for use by the Silverlight automation infrastructure.
member.returns: An automation peer for use by the Silverlight automation infrastructure.
member.remarks: This method returns an automation peer for the underlying Selector control. It creates a new automation peer instance if one has not been created; otherwise, it returns the automation peer previously created. The automation peer is included as a child by the AutoCompleteBox control. Classes that participate in the Silverlight automation infrastructure must implement this method to return a class-specific derived class of AutomationPeer that reports information for automation behavior.

member.name: T:System.Windows.Controls.TimeGlobalizationInfo
member.summary: Strategy object that determines how controls interact with DateTime and CultureInfo.
member.remarks: TimeInput supports only the following formatting characters: 'h', 'm', 's', 'H', 't'. All other characters are filtered out: 'd', 'f', 'F', 'g', 'K', 'M', 'y', 'z'.

member.summary: The characters that are allowed inside a format.

member.name: M:System.Windows.Controls.TimeGlobalizationInfo.GetTransformedFormat(System.String)
member.summary: Transforms a format to a format that only allows the characters h, m, s, t, H and the defined TimeSeparators (: and .). Also takes into account the rule that a single TimeCharacter should be followed by a space.
member.param: The format that needs to be transformed.
member.returns: A format containing only the expected characters.

member.name: M:System.Windows.Controls.TimeGlobalizationInfo.MapDigitToCharacter(System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns the global representation of each integer formatted by the TimeGlobalizationInfo.
member.param: Character that will be mapped to a different character.
member.returns: The global version of a character that represents the input.

member.name: M:System.Windows.Controls.TimeGlobalizationInfo.MapCharacterToDigit(System.Char)
member.summary: Returns the European number character of each global representation parsed by the TimeGlobalizationInfo.
member.param: The global version of the character that needs to be mapped to a regular character.
member.returns: The character that represents the global version of a character.
member.remarks: All characters pass through this method (whitespaces and TimeDesignators). Return the input character if no logical mapping could be made.

member.summary: Gets the actual TimeParsers that will be used for parsing.

member.returns: A new collection of parsers that represent the parsers this strategy object will use.

member.name: M:System.Windows.Controls.TimeGlobalizationInfo.FormatTime(System.Nullable{System.DateTime},System.Windows.Controls.ITimeFormat,System.Char[])
member.summary: Formats the specified DateTime to a time string representation.
member.param: The DateTime that should be formatted.
The time format used to describe how value should be formatted.
The allowed characters in the format. Leave empty to indicate that all characters are allowed. See remarks.
member.returns: A string that represents the time part of a DateTime.
member.remarks: The TimeFormat will contain TimeCharacters in a certain order, like hh:mm:ss. By passing specific TimeCharacters, these will get filtered and the method only returns part of the formatted string. Example: pass 'h', 't', 'H' to get back 4 AM, if the culture was set to en-US.

member.name: M:System.Windows.Controls.TimeGlobalizationInfo.ParseTime(System.String,System.Windows.Controls.ITimeFormat,System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{System.Windows.Controls.TimeParser})

member.param: The text that was entered by the user.
The TimeFormat instance used to supply formats.
member.returns: A DateTime with a correctly set time part.
member.remarks: The date part of the DateTime is irrelevant and will be overwritten by the current date.

member.returns: True, if the time was parsed correctly, false if the time was not parsed.

member.name: T:System.Windows.Controls.CatchallTimeParser
member.summary: TimeParser that will allow very loose time to be entered. It will try to parse the first two numbers as hours and the second two numbers as minutes, and will not care about other characters, such as designators, separators or non-time related characters. If the first character is bigger than 2, it will parse only the first character as an hour and will use the second two characters for minutes.

member.name: F:System.Windows.Controls.CatchallTimeParser.exp
member.summary: Expression used to parse.

member.name: M:System.Windows.Controls.CatchallTimeParser.TryParse(System.String,System.Globalization.CultureInfo,System.Nullable{System.DateTime}@)
member.summary: Tries to parse a string to a DateTime.
member.param: The text that should be parsed.
member.returns: True if the parse was successful, false if it was not.
member.remarks: The parsing is culture insensitive. A user can type 8p to indicate 20:00:00, or 20.
